body_html:
@asimshankar @skye graphs I use did not run on GPU between tf 1.6 and 1.8, but they did on 1.4 and they do now on 1.10-1.11. So, previously it was not only matter of load balancing, but also kind of a workaround for some bug. Currently it is only a way to implement load balancing.

I can provide serialized protobuf graph if you are interested, but this is a quite large convolutional network (frozen protobuf is about 100MB in size) and includes quite a bunch of different operations built on a similar to resnet arch. I think I have a smaller network which I can try to run on older TF now, if you are interested, and show you the graph, but right now current TF does run on GPU randomly selecting one from the set for each session run.

body:
@asimshankar @skye graphs I use did not run on GPU between tf 1.6 and 1.8, but they did on 1.4 and they do now on 1.10-1.11. So, previously it was not only matter of load balancing, but also kind of a workaround for some bug. Currently it is only a way to implement load balancing.

I can provide serialized protobuf graph if you are interested, but this is a quite large convolutional network (frozen protobuf is about 100MB in size) and includes quite a bunch of different operations built on a similar to resnet arch. I think I have a smaller network which I can try to run on older TF now, if you are interested, and show you the graph, but right now current TF does run on GPU randomly selecting one from the set for each session run.
